fields.value: Replication Data for: Is Temperature Exogenous? The Impact of Civil Conflict on the Instrumental Climate Record in Sub-Saharan Africa

dsDescriptionValue.value: Research into the effects of climate on political and economic outcomes assumes that short-term variation in weather is exogenous to the phenomena being studied.  However, weather data are derived from stations operated by national governments, whose political capacity and stability affect the quality and continuity of coverage.  We show that civil conflict risk in Sub-Saharan Africa is negatively correlated with the number and density of weather stations contributing to a country’s temperature record.  This effect is both cross-sectional—countries with higher average conflict risk tend to have poorer coverage—and cross-temporal—civil conflict leads to loss of weather stations.  Poor coverage induces a small downward bias in one widely used temperature data set, due to its interpolation method, and increases measurement error, potentially attenuating estimates of the temperature-conflict relationship.  Combining multiple observational data sets to reduce measurement error almost doubles the estimated effect of temperature anomalies on civil conflict risk.

publicationCitation.value: Schultz, Kenneth, and Justin Mankin. [date]. “Is Temperature Exogenous? The Impact of Civil Conflict on the Instrumental Climate Record in Sub-Saharan Africa.” American Journal of Political Science. Forthcoming. http://ajps.org/

fields.value:
This dataset underwent an independent verification process that replicated the tables and figures in the primary article. For the supplementary materials, verification was performed solely for the successful execution of code. Additionally, the scripts provided to construct the analysis datasets were not verified. The verification process was carried out by the Odum Institute for Research in Social Science at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

The associated article has been awarded the Open Materials Badge. Learn more about the Open Practice Badges from the Center for Open Science.



Note: The burquality variable for this manuscript is not available on the AJPS Dataverse due to the proprietary nature of the data. To request access to this variable please see these instructions.

files.description: Consists of grid-cell month level observations covering the land area of SSA at 1.0 degree resolution from 1946-2016. This file is used for tests on bias in section 2.
files.label: best_analysis.tab

files.description: Contains gridded monthly temperature data from the Berkeley Earth surface temperature (BEST) project.
files.label: best_gridded.tab

files.description: Contains station-month data on stations used in the BEST data set.
files.label: best_stations.tab

dataFile.description: Contains station-month data on stations used in the BEST data set.

files.description: Consists of country-year level observations for countries in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) in the period 1946-2016.  This file is used for all tests on country-year level analysis, including tests on coverage in section 1, on bias and measurement error in section 2, and the relationship between temperature and conflict in section 3.
files.label: country_analysis.tab

dataFile.description: Consists of country-year level observations for countries in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) in the period 1946-2016.  This file is used for all tests on country-year level analysis, including tests on coverage in section 1, on bias and measurement error in section 2, and the relationship between temperature and conflict in section 3.
